title: Sotheby’s International Realty’s Executive Says Customizing a Home is Key
text:
Julie Leonhardt LaTorre is the chief operating officer for Sotheby’s International Realty Affiliates LLC, and as such, is responsible for overseeing the global servicing and operations functions for the Sotheby's International Realty brand.

Before joining Sotheby’s International Realty Affiliates LLC, Ms. LaTorre worked on affiliate services at Christie’s International Real Estate. She has also held positions as a commercial real estate finance attorney at two leading Wall Street firms: Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton LLP and Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft LLP.

We caught up with the New Jersey-based Ms. LaTorre to discuss which areas of the world are most luxe, the best opportunities available in Europe, and more.

More: Design Firm Chief Says Luxury is About Tapping Into All the Senses

Mansion Global: Describe your dream property.

Julie Leonhardt LaTorre: We recently bought a 1930s farmhouse in New Jersey, and we have 16 acres, which is a dream after so many years living in a city. But I’d also love a luxury high-rise in London, something ultra modern. I like both extremes.



MG: Do you have a real estate property that got away?

JLL: I lived in Hoboken, New Jersey, for 15 years and there were so many of those. The real estate market has totally exploded there.



MG: What does luxury mean to you?

JLL: To me, it’s quiet, simple and understated. Clear lines, a modern feel. Everything has its purpose and place.

More: Luxury is About Inner Wellness, Says Los Angeles-Based Designer



MG: What area do you think is the next hub for luxury properties?

JLL: Secondary cities like Austin, Nashville and Kansas City. People are looking for more livable cities for primary homes.



And we’re still seeing lots of secondary home buying in Florida—in Naples and Miami and elsewhere.



MG: What’s the biggest surprise in the luxury real estate market now?

JLL: The surprising thing to me is that technology, as much as people talk about it, has not fundamentally changed the real estate industry. It hasn’t replaced agents in any way. We use technology to enhance our service, but it doesn’t replace the most fundamental thing—relationships.

From Penta: Guy Hands’ Business and Philanthropy

MG: Where are the best luxury homes in the world and why?

JLL: Luxury means different things to different people, but Telluride, Colorado, is one of my favorites at the moment. It’s very cosmopolitan but also beautiful.



In New York City, old, historical buildings that have been redone to feel new, like the Woolworth Tower.



In Europe, we see Portugal continue to be a place where people are looking, in part because of the Golden Visa program.

Singapore is amazing for its ultra luxury, super penthouses that have a minimum of 10,000 square feet, amazing views, and are in buildings with full concierge services.



MG: What’s your favorite part of your home?

JLL: Right now my favorite part is my chicken coop. Our chicks just started laying eggs. At the end of the day, I love to have a glass of wine and watch them run about. There’s just something about a big red barn.

More: New York Real Estate Investor and Developer Says Despite Challenges, Manhattan’s Market is Still a Leader

MG: What best describes the theme of your home and why?

JLL: I’ve kept the aesthetics very simple, focused on black and white. Things being clean and simple allows my mind to be at rest. We have giant windows so the outdoors becomes a focal point—trees or snow depending on the season.



MG: What’s the most valuable thing in your home?

JLL: My grandmother’s emerald ring. There’s also a piece of glass that I bought in Venice that brings me great joy.



MG: What’s the most valuable amenity to have in a home right now?

JLL: The ability to customize, whether it’s smart home technology, or the flow of the house. That’s really important to luxury buyers.

More: Designer Andre Fu Says a Home Should Reflect Its Neighborhood

MG: What’s your best piece of real estate advice?

JLL: Trust your instincts and buy something you love. Even if something looks good on paper but doesn’t feel right, skip it. Even if it’s for investment purposes, there should be something that excites you about it.



MG: What’s going on in the news that will have the biggest impact on the luxury real estate market?

JLL: There are a few things. People are feeling slightly insecure, so that can mean that real estate is a safer place to put money, but on the other hand they can be scared to invest, too.



Millennials are having greater and greater impacts as they age and buy houses.

More: Holistic Wellness is the Perk Buyers Really Want, Says NYC Brokerage Chief

MG: What is the best area now for investing in luxury properties?

JLL: Spain and Portugal. We’re seeing interest from buyers around the world. There are some great properties and still a lot of value.



We’re seeing a lot of activity in Canada and Japan—probably due to the Olympic games coming up there. And also in New Zealand, with high-end domestic buyers.



MG: If you had a choice of living in a new development or a prime resale property, which would you choose and why?

JLL: New development, all the way. There’s an opportunity to customize, to have those amenities that you want and to have things new and simple.



MG: What area currently has the best resale value?

JLL: It’s difficult to anticipate, as things feel uncertain. So now it’s more important than ever to have a real estate broker that you trust. Having someone who knows that can make a difference in the resale value.
